messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: We want to know why people can talk.
We need to look at our brains.
Our brains are different from animal brains.
It is not just about the size of the brain.
It is also important what our brains can do.
And it is important why they changed over a long time.

We do not have many clues about this.
Old things from long ago do not help.
They do not tell us how early people talked.
But we can look at old bones from early people.
We can see how their mouths, throats, and tongues changed.

About 100,000 years ago, people changed.
They could make many different sounds.
Before that time, scientists can only guess.
Did early people talk with simple sounds? We are not sure.

- While the BERTScore of 0.9052 is acceptable and the text correctly classifies as A2, these cannot override the failure to maintain the original's core meaning.

Suggestion: The text must be rewritten to preserve the concept of 'complex language' and 'evolution'. Rephrase the opening to focus on how humans learned to use difficult or complex words. Ensure the text explains that brains and bodies changed slowly over time, which is what 'evolution' means. The goal is simplification, not meaning alteration.
